responses.content: AI growth is outpacing plan, so we’re rebalancing partner-led scale motions to lean into these new workloads without abandoning legacy opportunities.
DeepSeek layers Moore’s Law improvements with AI scaling laws, making inference cheaper and enabling workloads to shift from massive cloud to capable local RTX PCs.
We remain committed to OpenAI while building a globally fungible training/inference fleet so CapEx serves the broadest set of workloads.
Copilot, Copilot Studio, and autonomous agents are the UI for Copilot Chat; they let IT teams ground copilots in enterprise data and orchestrate AI flows across workflows.
AI workloads stitch frontier, fine-tuned, distilled, and open models together, so we keep app servers evergreen as the best model mix evolves.
Copilot adoption begins with productivity teams but quickly spreads via shared Pages and collaborative workflows, fueling everyday usage.
Non-AI scale motions through partners are being rebalanced with updated coverage, marketing, and incentives to keep the mix healthy.
Azure AI exceeded expectations due to pulled-forward deliveries and Copilot traction, underlining durable pricing and seat growth.
We invest against ~$300B of RPO while shifting capex from long-lived facility builds toward fungible GPU/CPU/DPU capacity tied to contracted revenue.
Bookings strength was broad—renewals, upsells (Copilot), and large Azure commitments—so the beat wasn’t concentrated solely in the OpenAI tranche.

questions: Commercial bookings were solid, but Azure came in at the low end. What execution issues drove that miss, and is the back-half acceleration still intact?
Can you clarify the components behind the outsized Microsoft AI beat—especially Copilot—and how much of Azure AI contributed?
DeepSeek seems to bend the cost curve. How much cheaper is inference, and how long until that impacts customer ROI?
Can you frame the Stargate/OpenAI change—does Microsoft remain committed while scaling a fungible fleet, and how should investors think about CapEx?
With Copilot in market for over a year, how are you evolving the packaging and go-to-market to broaden adoption?
How much inference on Azure will be proprietary models vs. open models over time, and does that distinction matter?
Where is Copilot strength showing up—departmental expansion, usage intensity, or a shift from POCs to multi-department deployments?
Commercial RPO jumped $39B sequentially with 75% CC growth. Was this breadth across customers, a few large deals, or both?

metadata.source: NVDA Q2 FY2025 earnings call transcript
